So now, we have
decision time, we're

going to need to decide whether
to reject the null hypothesis.

So as we've said,
a small p value

suggests that such a large
value of the test statistic

is unlikely to occur
under the null hypothesis.

OK, so a small p value gives
us evidence against H naught,
but is it enough evidence?

Well, usually, we need to
have a binary decision.

We need to either reject
the null hypothesis

or else fail to reject
the null hypothesis.

I should mention, we never
accept the null hypothesis.

Because we're testing
the null hypothesis,
we either reject it or we don't.

But the right vocabulary
isn't to accept the null.

It's just to fail
to reject the null.
So OK, our p value is small.

That gives us some
evidence against H naught.
Should we reject the null?
Or should we not reject it?

Well, if it's really
small, we want
to reject the null hypothesis.

And that would correspond
to making a quote, unquote,

"discovery" where we've
discovered something new

and interesting about
the world, hopefully.
But how small is small enough?

So should we only reject
the null hypothesis,
if the p value is below 0.00001?

Or is it enough to reject
the null hypothesis provided
that the p value is below 0.01?

So oftentimes, 5% or
0.05 is used as a cutoff
for rejecting a null hypothesis.

But that's just an arbitrary
number that people use.

And I always tell my
students that the reality

is that how small
that cutoff should be

depends on how bad it is
to make a mistake here

and in particular,
what's called a type I

error, which I think Danielle
is going to introduce soon.

And we'll talk about
this more in a minute.

But that cutoff of 0.05
is very field specific.

And it's by no means a
gold standard in any way.

So, OK, the thing we
need to be thinking

about when we're doing
hypothesis testing
is this table.

So this is like
the table of truth.

So we have rows and we have
columns in this 2 by 2 table.

And the columns tell
us what reality is.

So the leftmost column
corresponds to the truth
being H naught.

So the null hypothesis
really holds.

And then the rightmost column
is under the alternative Ha,
which is the alternative holds.
So the null does not hold.

And then there's two possible
decisions we can make.
Those are shown in the rows.

Either we reject
the null hypothesis

or we do not reject
the null hypothesis.

And of course, in
reality, we never
know which column we're in.

We know which row we're in,
but not which column we're in.

Exactly because the rows
correspond to a decision
that we're making.

It's my choice whether or not
I reject the null hypothesis.
But I have no insight into--
or I don't know--
No certainty.

No certainty about
which column I'm in.

So there's four scenarios
that we can be in here.

So the first scenario
here, this corresponds
to the null hypothesis holding.

And I decide not
to reject H naught.
And this is great.
This is a good place to be.

Because it means that there was
nothing interesting going on

and I didn't reject
the null hypothesis.
Nothing to see here.
Let's move right along.
This is good.

In my courtroom example,
this corresponds

to the defendant being innocent
and they're not convicted.
That would be good.

OK, so this is another
thing we can be happy about.

Here, the null
hypothesis does not hold.

And we rejected the
null hypothesis.

So here, Gareth, how is
your defendant doing?
Well, guilty and convicted.

So we're happy
about that as well.
Well, probably.
Maybe not.
Some people might not be.

I guess, it depends
on what the crime
was and that type of thing.

But we don't need to
get into that, probably.

OK, so now here, this is
what's called a type II error.

And here, the alternative
hypothesis holds,

and we decided not to
reject the null hypothesis.

So this is known
as a type II error.
And in this situation, the--
we're actually good.

You tell us what happened
to your defendant.

Well, guilty, but
he got off for it.
So this is a situation where--
or she.
Or she.
Or they.
They, OK.

It could be, for example,
that the defendant was guilty.

There was evidence of guilt
but not overwhelming evidence.

And of course, on
a jury where we're

instructed that we should
not convict someone,

unless we have evidence
beyond reasonable doubt.

And a hypothesis test set
up is similar to that.
We may have suggestive evidence.

We may have a test statistic
that's relatively large

or a p value that's relatively
small, but not small enough

to actually be sure enough to
reject the null hypothesis.
Exactly.

All right, and then finally,
the fourth scenario.

Here, the null
hypothesis holds, but we
rejected the null hypothesis.

And this is known
as a type I error.

And type I errors
are what we try

to avoid when we're
doing hypothesis testing.

Or to put it in a
better way, it's not

that we try to avoid them,
we try to control them.

And saying that we
try to control them,

that's a statistical
way of saying

we want to make sure we're not
making too many type I errors.

So what's the type I error in
your courtroom example, Gareth?
Well, this is the worst one.
This is the innocent person.

She's innocent but
convicted of the crime.

So in this example,
finally, we have

someone who's innocent and
convicted of the crime,

and that's the woman
in this example.
All right, let's move on.

So the type I errors and type
II errors are both mistakes.

We want to ideally
avoid both of them.

Why is it the type
I error that you

chose to say, this is what
we really want to avoid?

This really has to
do with the asymmetry

between the null hypothesis
and the alternative.

The null hypothesis is
codifying our default state
of belief about the world.

And there's got to
be a lot of evidence

for us to change that
default state of belief.

So if we rejected the null
hypothesis, we're saying,

wow, there was just
a ton of evidence

that's causing us to change our
minds about how the world works,

change our entire
understanding of the world.

There must have been
a lot of evidence.

And we don't want to draw
conclusions like that
willy-nilly.

And that's why type I errors, we
really need to be careful about.

It's like if the
rejecting H naught

is the headline in
the newspaper, that's
like vitamin C cures cancer.

That's like you've
rejected H naught.

H naught is that vitamin
C does not cure cancer.

If the headline is that
vitamin C cures cancer,
somebody rejected H naught.

And we really, really,
really want to make sure
that they are right.

We do not want that
to be a type I error.

So in medical studies, we are
most worried about a type I

error because it suggests
that some treatment or drug

or whatever it is that we're
looking at is somehow has

a beneficial effect, that
in reality, it doesn't.

And obviously, that can
have a large impact.

But then a type Ii error
is also an issue here.

In practice, we would like
to have both small type
I and type II errors.

But the reality is that
to minimize one error,

you actually tend to make
the other one larger.

So there's always some trade-off
between the type I and type II
errors.

And the standard setup is that
we believe the type I error is
worse than a type II error.

So it's not that we
ignore the type II error,

we still want it to
be relatively small,

but we concentrate more
on the type I error.
Yeah.

And just to wrap
that thought up,

if you're familiar with the idea
of power, which we're not going

to get into today, the power of
a hypothesis testing procedure,

the power is 1 minus
the type II error.
So that's how--
Probability of a type II error.

Yeah, 1 minus the probability
of a type II error, thanks.
Great.

OK, so the type I error
rate is the probability
of making a type I error.

And what we're
going to want to do

is we're going to want the
type I error rate to be small.

And it turns out that there's
a really easy way to do this.

If we only ever reject H
naught when the p value is

less than alpha, then
the type I error rate
will be at most alpha.

So if you feel in your heart
that you want your type I error

rate to be no more
than 0.05, then you

should just reject the null
hypothesis whenever the p value
is less than 0.05 and so on.

Or if you want your type I
error rate to be 0.01 or 0.001,

then you should reject
the null hypothesis

whenever the p value
is below 0.01 or 0.001.

Or physicists will sometimes
choose much, much smaller p

values here because they'd
like to be very, very certain
about what they're doing.

Well, the way that I would
think about that as well is,

think about what
your sample size is.

If you're running
some kind of a study

and your sample size
is 20 or 30 or 40,

it'll hard to accrue
enough evidence against H

naught to get a
fantastically small p value.

But by contrast, if
you are like Google

and your sample size is
every click on the Google.com

homepage in the
last four days, you

have a fantastically
large sample size.

Or similarly, if
you're a physicist

and you're studying subatomic
particles or whatever,

you might have a really,
really big sample size.

And then you can afford
to use an alpha that's 10
to the negative 6 or something.

But that raises
another issue here

that if your sample
size is large enough,

it is actually relatively easy
to end up with a very small p

value, but only a very
small difference, say,

in the means between the
control and treatment mice.

Let's say, we found a million
mice lying around somewhere,

we perform these
hypothesis tests,

we're very likely to get
a very small p value.
But that doesn't by itself--

Assuming that the
alternative holds.

Assuming that the null
hypothesis doesn't hold.

But the reality is that the
null hypothesis almost never
exactly holds.

So if there's a very, very small
difference between the control

and treatment mice, if I have
a large enough sample size,

I'm almost certain to get a
small p value, even if there's
a very, very small difference.

So sometimes, people equate a
small p value with telling us

that there's a large
effect going on.

And the reality is that if
you have a large sample size,

it might only be a
very small difference.

You're just sure
there is a difference,

but we don't actually know
how big that difference is.
Yeah, that's absolutely true.

And this is the difference
between statistical significance
and practical significance.

So often, if the
p value is below,

let's say, 0.05 or 0.01
or 0.001 or whatever

threshold someone's
using, they'll

say that it's
statistically significant.

Well, that doesn't mean that
it's practically significant
or scientifically important.

Gareth, just before
we leave this slide,

I want to hear more
about this scenario

where you found a million
mice lying around.

We just started remodeling
our guest house.

All right, Los Angeles, I
guess, it must be a thing.
